719412f-b.title: Manhattan: East Broadway - Market Street
719412f-b.text:
68 East Broadway, adjoining the .W. corner of Market Street, show-
ing two views of Botanic Hall where .ontinental Lodge No. 287, F and
A.M., New york City was constitutea on April 22, 1853. They remained
in this Masonio Temple for two years; the Lodge room being on the
upper floor according to Dr. Frank Law of Flushing, Long Island, the
last descendant of his line. At this time Doric Lodge No. 280 and
Independent Lodge No. 185 met here also, this being a well known center
of Masonic activities. Botanic Hall was on the second floor, the
store being occupied by Law and Boyd, Botanioal Pharmacists, who
later bought the building. The original picture was talen from a
yellowed billhead of this firm showing an old wood cut engraving of
this structure as it appeared when Metropolitan Medical College was an
occupant. Percy Boyd Plumb, the last descendant of the Boyds and who
continued the business until 1916 supplied this, and is the authority
for the statement that Abraham Lincoln spoke here on the occasion of
his memorable visit to New York when he spoke at Cooper Union.
Trows City Directory first lists the College at this address in the
1857 edition. Note the lantern hanging over the stairway door at the
left, with the square and compasses which were lighted on Lodge nights.
In the rear, above the fifth floor there is a two room apartment
that is believed to still remain. Francis J. Arkins, Past Master and
Historian of Continental Lodge No. 287 and Secretary of the Masonic
Board of Relief of New York City unearthed this after a five year
search, completing the collection of the total number of Masonic
Temples in which Continental Lodge has met since 1853. An air brushed
view removing the College signs accompanies this and shons this building
as it originally appeared.
719412f-b.folder: East Broadway & Market Street, Manhattan, NY

719412f-a.folder: East Broadway & Market Street, Manhattan, NY

719411f.title: Manhattan: East Broadway - Market Street
719411f.text:
70 to 66 East Broadway, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of
Market Street, showing adjoining the corner, a 5-story structure,
No. 68,which is supposed to have been the first place where stereoptican
and shadow views were first shown. It also is reputed to have had the
first public meeting rooms on this thoroughfare. In the vacant store
beneath the Hall, one Elias A. Cohen conducted an Indian Herb business
in 1900.
December 2, 1937.
George D. Chinn.
719411f.folder: East Broadway & Market Street, Manhattan, NY

719413f-a.title: Manhattan: East Broadway - Market Street
719413f-a.text:
East Broadway, west from but not including Market Street, as seen
from the Manhattan Bridge.
June 7, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
719413f-a.folder: East Broadway & Market Street, Manhattan, NY

721640f-a.title: Manhattan: Market Street - East Broadway
721640f-a.text:
(1)
Mcrket Street, west side, north from and including East Broadway,
to and including Bayard Street. The Second Ave., Elevated is
shown on Division Street.
June 7, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
